Understanding the influence of carbon nanomaterials on microbial communities

Keywords: Fullerene MWCNTs SWCNTs Graphene Microbial communities Toxicity mechanism
A B S T R A C T
Carbon nanomaterials (CNMs) are widely used because of their unique advantages in recent years. At the same time, the influence of CNMs on the environment is becoming increasingly prominent. This review mainly introduces the research progress in the effects of fullerenes, multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), singlewalled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and graphene on microorganisms and their toxicity mechanisms. On this basis, we have analyzed beneficial and adverse effects of fullerenes, graphene, MWCNTs and SWCNTs to microorganisms, and discussed the similarities of the toxicity mechanisms of different CNMs on microorganisms. This review helps provide ideas on how to protect microorganisms from the impacts of carbon nanomaterials, and it will be conductive to providing a strong theoretical basis for better application of carbon nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, CNMs have been widely used due to their unique performance advantages. Nowadays, the most widely used CNMs are mainly fullerene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene (Zhang et al., 2013). Besides, in recent years, the production of CNMs has shown an increasing trend. In 2011, the production of CNTs and graphene was about 5000 tons and 3000 tons respectively, which was about ten times that of the past ten years (Chen et al., 2018; De Volder et al., 2013). Due to good electrical conductivity, graphene and CNTs are often used as substitutes for copper and costly silver and silicon in electronic equipment (Aitola et al., 2015; Benwadih et al., 2014; Lekawa-Raus et al., 2014; Politou et al., 2016; Soldano et al., 2013), which is of great significance for alleviating heavy metal consumption and environmental pollution. In medicine, fullerenes and graphene are often used as carriers for drug-targeted transport and have shown positive effects in disease control (Hassanzadeh et al., 2017; Loh et al., 2018; Mehra et al., 2018; Youssef et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2017; Zhao et al., 2017). In addition, CNMs are often found in materials such as concrete, flame retardants, and catalysts, and they greatly improve the performance of these materials (Fang et al., 2008; Huang et al., 2012; Kashiwagi et al., 2005; Liu et al., 2014; Morsy et al., 2011; Norhasri et al., 2017). MWCNTs promote the growth and photosynthesis of green plants,
because MWCNTs can increase the effective photochemical quantum yield and promote the expression of photosynthesis proteins (Fan et al., 2018). Moreover, functionalized MWCNTs on silicon have a very good effect on the adsorption of triazine herbicides in aqueous solution (D'Archivio et al., 2018). From the discovery of fullerenes in 1985 to the discovery of graphene in 2004, the unique physics and chemical character of CNMs has become a hot research topic, which has led to an extensive and in-depth research.
Fullerenes refer to molecules having a hollow spherical or tubular structure composed entirely of carbon atoms (Taylor and Walton, 1993). In 1985, Harold Walter Kroto et al. (1985) discovered the first fullerene molecule-C60. Its shape resembles a 32-faced football with a diameter of about 0.7 nm (David, 1992). At present, fullerenes are mainly obtained by a graphite arc method (Gao et al., 2003). Fullerenes are widely used. For example, C60 is lubricious so that it may become a super lubricant. In addition, C60 is also often used as battery materials and semiconductor materials (Guldi and Prato, 2000).
CNTs are seamless and hollow nanotubes formed by single-layer or multi-layer graphite sheets curled around the center at a certain angle, whose diameters range from hundreds of picometers to dozens of nanometers. CNTs are one of the most important one-dimensional nanomaterials at present, which are characterized by high strength, low density, superior stealth and strong hydrophobicity. So that they are

Graphene is an allotrope of carbon with excellent mobility, remarkable room temperature Hall effect, stable Dirac electronic structure, excellent light transmission, high mechanical strength and thermal conductivity. Because graphene has so many excellent properties, it is widely used in the manufacture of batteries, semiconductors, sensors and capacitors, etc. At present, the researches on the application of graphene have made a series of important progress in many fields such as chemistry, materials, physics, biology, environment and energy (Zhu et al., 2010).
With the increasing application of CNMs, CNMs have created great economic and social benefits for humans and society, but their adverse effects on the environment and various organisms have gradually emerged. CNMs not only cause the embryonic death of animals but also inhibit the growth of animals and plants, and CNTs released from composite materials are also considered as potential sources of environmental pollution (Chen et al., 2017b; Laux et al., 2018). In particular, microorganisms have important value in the restoration and improvement of the ecological environment and the maintenance of ecological balance. In addition, compared with physical and chemical methods, the use of microorganisms to repair polluted environment has the advantages of low cost and remarkable effects (Chen et al., 2017b; Chen et al., 2015). In summary, studying the effects of CNMs on microbial communities is of great significance.

sections.heading: 2. Effects of fullerene on microbial communities
2.1. Recent progress
sections.text:
In the soil environment, previous studies have shown that fullerene could alter the biomass and structure of microorganisms. Hao et al. (2018) investigated the toxicity influence of fullerene on microbial communities in a fertile fullerene-treated potted soil by testing bacterial community composition after 30 days exposure. They found that the amount of Nitrospira, Planctomyces and Lysobacter reduced as the concentration of fullerene increased (50–500mg/kg) (Fig. 1). Also, they
indicated that high concentrations (500mg/kg) of fullerene increased the bio-carbon content in soil (Fig. 1), which can be applied to detect soil organic matter balance because the bio‑carbon content is a main indicator of soil organic matter balance in a plant-soil-microbe ecosystem (Thakur et al., 2015). Tong et al. (2007) separately added a suspension of fullerenes (1 μg/g) and granular fullerenes (1000 μg/g) to the corn field soil, and then examined the structure and function of the microbial communities in the two soil samples, they found that there was little change in the number and community structure of microorganisms in the two soil samples. Johansen et al. (2008) added different doses (0, 5, 25 and 50mg/kg) of fullerenes to the clay loam, and then they found that very small doses (0 and 5mg/kg) of fullerenes had little effect on microbial respiration, but a certain dose (25 and 50mg/ kg) of fullerenes reduced the number of fast-growing bacteria by about 3–4 times (exposure for 3 days) (Fig. 1), and this decline trend was barely observed after 23 days. Previous studies have shown that fullerenes incorporated into soil could be absorbed by plants. Moreover, fullerenes absorbed by plants are not easily decomposed and are easily accumulated in plants (Avanasi et al., 2014), which will change the influence of fullerenes on microorganisms in the soil. Related studies have shown that fullerene can also have an indirect effect on soil microbes by affecting plants. For example, fullerenes can promote the production of crops (Monica and Cremonini, 2014), which may cause crops to absorb more nutrients such as inorganic salts and organic matter from the soil, thereby limiting the survival of soil microorganisms Nyberg et al. (2008) examined the community structure of archaea, bacteria and eukaryotes in anaerobic digesters containing fullerenes (8.6 mg/kg) and anaerobic digesters containing no fullerenes. They found the community structure in the two sludge samples did not differ significantly, and they concluded that fullerenes had no toxicity or effects on anaerobic microorganisms, which was inconsistent with the above tested conclusions. In topsoil with large amounts of organic matter and clay, Tong et al. (2007) found that fullerenes had little impact on the structure of microbial communities. Similarly, Berry et al. (2017) indicated that fullerene had a significant effect on microorganisms in soils containing a small amount of clay and organic matter, from which it can be inferred that organic matter and clay in soil can alleviate the adverse effects of fullerene on microbial
communities. In addition, for the functionalized fullerene material, fullerol, it had a higher mineralization rate and mineralization degree in soils containing a large amount of organic matter and clay than that in soils with little organic matter and clay (Berry et al., 2017), which also confirmed the above inference to some extent.
In the aquatic environment, fullerene can change the abundance and structure of microbial communities (Fig. 1). However, Blaise et al. (2008) tested the toxicity of nine nanomaterials such as C60 and SWCNTs on aquatic microorganisms (e.g., Vibrio fischeri). They exposed aquatic microorganisms to C60-treated water samples. After 21 days, it was found that C60 had little effect on the number of microorganisms and community structure compared to the other eight nanomaterials. Similarly, Lawrence et al. (2016a) found that the effect of fullerenes on aquatic microorganisms was significantly lower than that of CNTs by comparing the effects of fullerenes and CNTs on microorganisms in natural river water. Kang et al. (2007) indicated that direct contact between bacteria and CNMs could cause bacteria cell deform or rupture. Besides, the related investigation also found that long-term exposure of microorganisms to fullerenes could reduce microbial cell viability and membrane integrity significantly (Kang et al., 2009) (Fig. 1). Other studies have shown that fullerene exhibited significant toxic effects on Escherichia coli (Lyon et al., 2007), but it had little toxicity to Bacillus subtilis in aquatic environments, which may be due to the strong anti-peptidoglycan in the surface layer of Bacillus subtilis cells that has protected themselves against fullerenes (Kang et al., 2009). Li et al. (2008) mixed different doses of humic acid and fulvic acid from the Suwannee River as a natural organic matter, and then they mixed the natural organic matter with fullerenes (1 mg/L) into a solution. Escherichia coli was added to the above solution and their growth conditions were observed. As a result, it was found that the Escherichia coli's growth rate and their carbon dioxide production in the solution were significantly lower than those in the control group (without fullerene). However, as the content of natural organic matter increased, the carbon dioxide production and the growth rate of Escherichia coli also increased. This is similar to the previous results on soil organic matter that inhibits fullerenes' toxicity to microorganisms.
In a word, fullerenes can change the population structure of microorganisms and biomass in both water and soil, and the degree of influence varies with the species of microorganisms and the concentration of fullerenes (Fig. 1), but in general, fullerene has a less effect on microorganisms than other nanomaterials (Jia et al., 2005; Kang et al., 2009; Lawrence et al., 2016b; Wang et al., 2014), and organic matter can alleviate the effects of fullerenes on microorganisms.

sections.heading: 2.2. Toxicity mechanism of fullerene to microorganisms
sections.text: Currently, there are many reports have proved that fullerene exhibit antimicrobial properties (Fang et al., 2007). However, the mechanism of its antibacterial properties has not been clearly established yet. Referring to the mechanism of the toxicity of fullerene to microorganisms, related research suggested that fullerene could block the electron transfer between microbial cells because of its high electron affinity, leading to cell death (Lyon et al., 2007) (Fig. 2A). Deryabin et al. (2015) found that Escherichia coli is highly sensitive to fullerene, probably because fullerene can change the electrostatic balance in Escherichia coli cells. In addition, fullerenes also disrupt the normal secretion of enzymes in microbial cells (Chen et al., 2017c), causing the cells to lose balance in metabolism.

sections.heading: 3. Effects of MWCNTs on microbial communities
3.1. Recent progress
sections.text:
In the soil environment, previous researches have shown that MWCNTs have effects on microorganisms. Ge et al. (2016) added MWCNTs (1mg/g) to dry soil. After one year, they found that the
microbial biomass was greatly dropped (Fig. 1). Through PCR sequencing and other methods, it was also found that the MWCNTs greatly changed the bacterial composition (Fig. 1), but the fungal community did not alter compared to soil samples without MWCNTs. Chung et al. (2011) by in-depth studies on microbial communities in landscape base soil containing MWCNTs (5000mg/kg) demonstrated that in a short period of time, microbial enzyme activity and microbial biomass would show a downward trend (Fig. 1). Ge et al. (2018) added different amounts (0, 0.1, 100, or 1000mg/kg) of MWCNTs to the agricultural topsoil (0–20 cm depth), and then they discovered that in the vegetative stage of plants, microbial communities could only be affected when the content of MWCNTs in the soil was extremely low, which was manifested in an increase in the number of bacteria (Fig. 1). Another study (Shrestha et al., 2013) did not observe changes of soil respiration, soil enzyme activity and microbial community composition in sandy loam soil containing bits of MWCNTs (10 and 100mg/kg) after 90 days exposure. However, fungal fatty acids were observed in soil samples treated with the highest MWCNTs content (10,000mg/kg). With the addition of methyl ester markers, they performed pyrosequencing on the soil sample treated with the highest MWCNTs content (10,000mg/ kg) and found that the richness of bacteria capable of degrading soil contaminants such as Derxia, Holophaga, Opitutus and Waddlia was reduced, but the abundance of Rhodococcus, Pseudomonas, Nocardia and Pseudomonas showed an upward trend. In other words, high content of MWCNTs in the soil can promote the transformation of dominant microbial communities into microbial populations that are more tolerant to MWCNTs in the soil (Fig. 1). In addition, in the soil, the effect of treated MWCNTs on microorganisms is also significant. Kerfahi et al. (2015) added different concentrations (0, 50, 500 and 5000 μg/g) of natural MWCNTs and acid-treated MWCNTs to two overgrown soil samples. After 8 weeks, they found that in the two soil samples the diversity of bacteria has not changed, but compared with natural MWCNTs, acid-treated MWCNTs could significantly change the community composition of soil bacteria, which was manifested by an increase in the number of bacteria that are resistant to acid-treated MWCNTs.
In the aquatic environment, MWCNTs also have various effects on microorganisms. An in-depth study on the bacterial community structure in wastewater containing MWCNTs was conducted. They pointed out that in a long period of time, MWCNTs (20mg/L) could adversely affect nutrient and COD removal in activated sludge treatment, and it also could significantly reduce microbial content and bacterial diversity (Fig. 1), which might result in a decrease in the effectiveness of sewage treatment. However, low concentration (1mg/L) of MWCNTs increased the number of glycogen accumulating organisms after long-term exposure (Hai et al., 2014) (Fig. 1). It was found that MWCNTs may be involved in microbial cells to cause rupture to microbial cells (Yadav et al., 2016) (Fig. 1), which may cause changes in the content of certain substances in the microbial cell，and the higher the content of MWCNTs, the more serious the damage to microbial cells, such as cytoplasmic loss. Hai et al. (2014) indicated that MWCNTs have a variety of structures, in which a sharp structure could destroy the microbial cells. Zhang et al. (2015) found that MWCNTS could promote the growth (> 50%) of atrazine-degrading microorganisms at low concentrations (25mg/L) (Fig. 1), which was possibly because MWCNTS promoted the expression of related genes, accelerated the cell division and cell growth (Khodakovskaya et al., 2012). By studying microorganisms in wastewater mixed with petroleum, it was discovered that MWCNTs cannot damage the microorganisms which play a great role in petroleum bioremediation. Conversely, MWCNTs might promote their growth (Abbasian et al., 2016) (Fig. 1). Studies have also shown that dissolved organic matter in a liquid environment can reduce the toxicity of MWCNTs to microorganisms, which is mainly due to the adsorption or encapsulation of CNTs by organic matter and the adsorbed or encapsulated CNTs loses its mobility. The higher the content of organic matter, the more obvious this effect is (Kang et al., 2009).
MWCNTs both promote and inhibit the growth of microorganisms. And the effects of MWCNTs on microorganisms depend on the type of microorganisms, the external environment, and the concentration and structure of MWCNTs. Compared with other factors, surface sorption capacity influenced by different size and functionalization of MWCNTs can be a more important factor that has a greater impact on toxicity. Since MWCNTs can form hollow structures equipped with large surface area in an aqueous environment, which will facilitate the adsorption of pollutants, thereby regulating the toxicity of pollutants and MWCNTs to microorganisms, and the sorption capacity is directly related to their size or diameter, within a certain range, the larger the specific surface area, the greater their adsorption of pollutants (Fan et al., 2018). Similarly, functionalization of MWCNTs can also influence the surface sorption ability of MWCNTs, among them, the acid-functionalized MWCNTs have stronger adsorption capacity than ordinary MWCNTs, and the adsorption capacity is proportional to the time of functionalization (D'Archivio et al., 2018). Besides, the formation of agglomerates in aqueous environments also has an impact on toxicity, its loose threedimensional structure provides more adsorption sites for pollutants and also captures a large number of microorganisms, thereby reducing the number and variety of microorganisms (Akasaka and Watari, 2009;
Kang et al., 2008) (Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 3.2. Toxicity mechanism of MWCNTs to microorganisms
sections.text:
So far, there are three main mechanisms for the toxicity of CNMs to microorganisms (Nel et al., 2006): (1) CNMs can produce the reactive oxygen species in cells that are in contact with itself (Yan et al., 2006); (2) CNMs can directly create damage on the bacterial cell membrane, which leads to a series of injuries (Fenoglio et al., 2008); (3) The toxicity of CNMs is related to their chemical and physical structure (Hai et al., 2014). At present, the first and the second explanations have gained more recognition than the other one explanation above. Bai et al. (2011) have indicated that MWCNTs could damage the cell membrane of Streptococcus mutans. Through a large number of experiments, Kang et al. (2008) also found that direct contact between MWCNTs and microbial cells could cause damage to microbial cell walls or cell membranes, resulting in a large loss of intracellular substances such as DNA and RNA (Fig. 2C). In addition, the destruction of the cell membranes will cause the cells to lose the functions of phagocytosis and pinocytosis, and also cause the loss of some biochemical reaction sites in the microorganisms, which eventually leads to cells
death (Fig. 2C). MWCNTs entering the cells could promote the cells to produce more reactive oxygen species, causing different degrees of damage to DNA, proteins and other substances in the cells (Chen et al., 2018; Jia et al., 2005; Shvedova et al., 2012) (Fig. 2C). The above mechanisms can reasonably explain the various observed effects of MWCNTs on microorganisms.

sections.heading: 4. Effects of SWCNTs on microbial communities
4.1. Recent progress
sections.text:
In the soil environment, many researches have indicated that SWCNTs could change the structure and the biomass of microbial communities. In order to determine the influence of the SWCNTs on soil microbial communities, Jin et al. (2014) added SWCNTs (0.03–1mg/g) to the overgrown topsoil samples (0–15 cm) and they found that with the increase of the content of SWCNTs, the number of major microorganisms presented a downward trend through statistical analyses. However, compared to soil samples without SWCNTs, the abundance of bacteria increases with the concentration of SWCNTs in the soil. Besides they also indicated that gram-positive bacteria could response to the effects of SWCNTs by changing the composition of intracellular lipids. Rodrigues and Elimelech (2010) indicated that SWCNTs greatly reduced the microbial biomass of Escherichia coli. Zhou et al. (2013) found that the degree of influence of SWCNTs on microbial communities was closely related to the content of SWCNTs through studying the microorganisms in paddy soils with SWCNTs. When the content of SWCNTs was extremely high, the microbial activity and enzyme activity in the soil will decrease greatly (Fig. 1). When the content of SWCNTs was very low, the microbial community in the soil did not change obviously compared to soil without SWCNTs. Nowadays, scholars' research on SWCNTs is not limited to natural SWCNTs, and researches on functionalized SWCNTs are also increasing. Tong et al. (2012) added three kinds of SWCNTs (natural SWCNTs, and polyethylene glycol functionalized SWCNTs and m-polyaminobenzene sulfonic acid functionalized SWCNTs at concentrations of 10, 15, 25 and 50 μg/mL) to soil samples with high organic content and soil samples with low organic content respectively. After 6 weeks, they discovered that all the three kinds of SWCNTs reduced the CO2 output in soil respirations and gross microbial biomass, but the functionalized SWCNTs had a more significant effect on microorganisms. At the same time, they also found that compared with soil samples with low organic matter content, the microbial community had a small degree of change such as biomass reduction in soil samples with high organic matter content. By studying the toxicity of functionalized SWCNTs to soil microbial communities, Rodrigues et al. (2013) indicated that different microbial communities reacted differently to carboxyl functionalized SWCNTs: most microbial communities could return to their original state in a short time after being affected by carboxyl-functionalized SWCNTs, but the fungal community could not. Besides, they also found that the degree of influence of SWCNTs on microorganisms in soil was also strongly related to the cycle of carbon and phosphorus in soil. In addition, some studies have pointed out that the special conformational changes of SWCNTs could greatly reduce the possibility of its degradation. By studying the conformational changes of SWCNTs after contacting with nanomaterialdegrading enzymes, Chen et al. (2016a) found that SWCNTs could adjust the distance between LiP and MnP residues to avoid degradation. Via establishing and observing the model of microbial catalytic oxidation of organic pollutants and lignin, it was found that SWCNTs could obviously reduce or increase the hydrogen bond stability and hydrophobicity between the ligand and the biological enzyme (Chen et al., 2016b). And SWCNTs also can alter the behavior of water molecules during catalytic oxidation and the conformation of N- and C-terminals of biocatalytic enzymes, thereby changing the normal degradation process of organic pollutants and lignin. Besides, both SWCNTs and functionalized SWCNTs could change the conformation of certain
microbial enzymes in the soil (Fig. 1), which may adversely affect microorganisms (Chen et al., 2017d).
In the aquatic environment, many studies have proved that SWCNTs are toxic to microorganisms. Besides, numerous investigations have indicated that the diameter of CNMs can affect their toxicity to microorganisms. Liu et al. (2009) pointed out that in a liquid environment, the toxicity of SWCNTs in a separately dispersed state was significantly greater than the toxicity of MWCNTs in an aggregated state, because SWCNTs, which are individually dispersed in solution, can behave as a number of moving “nano-darts”, which may continue to damage bacterial cells, leading to bacterial cell rupture or even death. Luongo and Zhang (2010) found that SWCNTs could inhibit the respiration of activated sludge in wastewater treatment systems in a short period of time. In addition, low concentrations (219mg/L) of SWCNTs can also be used in sludge systems, which can promote the growth of bacteria that degrade pollutants, predominating them in the microbial community (Fig. 1), and promoting the degradation of certain pollutants (Goyal et al., 2010). By measuring the structure of microbial treated with 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, and 3.5 g/L of SWCNTs, Qu et al. (2015) found that SWCNTs could protect microorganisms that degrade phenolic substances in phenol-containing wastewater and significantly improved the removal rate of phenol in wastewater (Fig. 1), which indicated that the toxicity of SWCNTs to the activated sludge microbial community varied with different microorganisms. In addition, Parise and Zhang (2014) investigated the influence of short SWCNTs, long SWCNTs, functionalized short SWCNTs and functionalized long SWCNTs on microbial communities in the sewage treatment system. They found that long SWCNTs exhibited higher toxicity to microorganisms than short SWCNTs. Similarly, functionalized SWCNTs had a significantly greater impact on microbial communities than the natural SWCNTs. This is because microbial respiration and the diversity of microorganisms in the sewage treatment systems with long SWCNTs and functionalized SWCNTs were greatly reduced compared to the sewage treatment systems with natural SWCNTs and short SWCNTs.
Through in-depth understanding of SWCNTs, we found that observations have shown that when the concentration of SWCNTs in the soil was low, the metabolic activities of microorganisms associated with the degradation of organic compounds in the soil will be enhanced (Fig. 1), which will promote the circulation of substances in the soil and enhance the soil fertility by enhancing N and P availability in a short time (Qian et al., 2018), which could be compared with the effects of MWCNTs. The toxic effects of SWCNTs on microorganisms vary depending on the type of microorganisms and whether SWCNTs are modified by other groups and so on.

sections.heading: 4.2. Toxicity mechanism of SWCNTs to microorganisms
sections.text:
Although SWCNTs and MWCNTs differ in physical structures and chemical properties, compared with MWCNTs, SWCNTs may exhibit greater biotoxicity (Qu et al., 2016). Referring to the toxicity mechanism of SWCNTs on microbial communities, previous studies have shown that oxidative stress is the main toxicity mechanism of SWCNTs to microorganisms, SWCNTs can induce a large amount of reactive oxygen species in cells, thereby damaging cell membranes and various substances in cells (Chen et al., 2018; Jia et al., 2005; Shvedova et al., 2012) (Fig. 2D). Besides, most researches proved that SWCNTs could enter the cells through the cell-derived and phagocytosis of microbial cells, attaching to the structure of organelles and other structures in the microbial cells, changing the morphology and function of the organelle (Fig. 2D). And for microorganisms with nucleus, SWCNTs can enter the nucleus and alter the structure of nucleic acids, inhibiting DNA transcription, which can have varying degrees of impact on microorganisms (Chen et al., 2013; Ong et al., 2016). Liu et al. (2009) observed the effects of pure SWCNTs on Escherichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus subtilis, and concluded that SWCNTs mainly enter the microbial cells through physical puncture to destroy the cell structure (Fig. 2D).
The softer the cell wall or membrane, the easier the SWCNTs enter, and the more damage the cells obtained. The toxicity mechanisms of SWCNTs and MWCNTs on microorganisms are similar. They can destroy the cell walls or cell membranes of microbial cells by direct contact with microbial cells and induce cells to produce reactive oxygen species to damage the structure and function of the cells, but the degree of damage to cells by SWCNTs is higher than that of MWCNTs, SWCNTs can destroy the materials inside the cell directly, but there is little literature on the ability of MWCNTs to destroy them directly, MWCNTs may only cause damage to them indirectly through reactive oxygen species (Fig. 2C and D).

sections.heading: 5.1. Recent progress
sections.text:
In the soil environment, graphene has a significant impact on microbial communities, which may be due to that the graphene has smaller diameter, larger surface area and stronger surface antibacterial ability compared to MWCNTs, SWCNTs and fullerenes (Qu et al., 2015). There is a suspicion that the influence of graphene on microbial community may be different from other CNMs. In order to further understand the influences of graphene on soil microbial communities and their mechanisms, Ren et al. (2015) used quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and pyrosequencing to analyze the number of microorganisms and the community structure of microorganisms in soil samples treated with graphene at different times. They found that graphene had a significant influence on the number of microorganisms and microbial community structure in soil (Fig. 1), and these effects are clearly related to the contact time of graphene and microorganisms. This study indicated that a small amount of graphene (< 100mg/kg) could increase soil microbial enzyme activity and bacterial biomass in a short time (Fig. 1), which increased the removal rate of pollutants in the soil. But over time, the activity of microbial enzymes and bacterial biomass in the soil returned to their original levels. Besides, this study also found that when the concentration of graphene in the soil was extremely high, the number of bacteria involved in soil ammoxidation, such as black pine fungus and digestive spirochete was significantly reduced (Fig. 1), which may cause adverse influences on the nitrogen cycle in the soil. In addition, some researches also pointed out that low dose of graphene oxide might increase cell attachment and proliferation (Fig. 1), which could promote the growth of cells (Ruiz et al., 2011). Du et al. (2015) obtained the following conclusions through experiments: graphene oxide greatly altered the structure and composition of soil bacterial communities, which mainly led to the increase of some nitrogen-fixing bacteria and iron-reducing bacteria. Hao et al. (2018) conducted an in-depth study of microorganisms in paddy soil. They found that compared with the control (without graphene oxide) the number of microorganisms in soil decreased with the increase of graphene oxide (50–500mg/kg). Graphene oxide can disrupt the oxidative balance in plants, thereby inhibiting plant growth and photosynthesis (Du et al., 2016). In addition, by investigating the effects of ion concentration in soil on graphene migration rate, Lanphere et al. (2013) found that the rate of graphene migration in soil decreased with increasing ion intensity. Besides, related studies have shown that in addition to the ion concentration, the organic matter and inorganic salts in the soil will also affect the migration movement of graphene. This effect is mainly due to the adsorption or encapsulation of graphene by organic matter and inorganic matter in the soil. The adsorbed or encapsulated graphene loses its mobility and the higher the content of inorganic salts and organic matter, the more obvious this effect is (Dinesh et al., 2012).
In the aquatic environment, the effects of graphene on microbial communities are similar to those in soil environments. In addition, studies have found that graphene is significantly more toxic to microorganisms without a membrane structure than microorganisms with
membrane structure (Akhavan and Ghaderi, 2010). However, due to the low dispersibility of graphene in a liquid environment, the current application of graphene in an aquatic environment is not widespread. But with the deeper research on graphene, it has been found that the stability, dispersibility and toxicity of polymer-graphene oxide composites in liquid environment were significantly higher than that of nature graphene (Mejias Carpio et al., 2012). Polymer-graphene oxide could change the composition of intracellular substances by attacking microbial cells, ultimately destroying cell structure and leading to cell death (Mejias Carpio et al., 2012). On the other hand, graphene oxide was not easily degraded in the environment due to its high stability (Kurapati et al., 2015). In response to the above problems, Chen et al. (2017a) explored the degradation methods of graphene and graphene composites. They compared microbial degradation methods with enzymatic degradation methods and finally found that the degradation ability of microorganisms on graphene and composite graphene materials was significantly higher than that of enzymes.
By studying the influence of graphene on microorganisms in soil and water environment, it was found that the influence of graphene on microorganisms in water environment is lower than that on soil microorganisms due to its low solubility in water. In addition, the toxicity of graphene oxide is significantly higher than that of graphene, but it is difficult to degrade in the environment. Besides, organic matter can affect the migration of graphene in the soil, which may provide new ideas for the application of graphene. For example, organic matter can be used as an adsorption carrier and transport carrier for graphene.

sections.heading: 5.2. Toxicity mechanism of graphene to microorganisms
sections.text: It is generally believed that the main mechanism of toxicity of graphene to microorganisms is oxidative stress (Zhu et al., 2017). Graphene can attack cell membranes, lipids, proteins, etc. In microbial cells, graphene makes the anti-oxidation and oxidation of microbial cells imbalance (Fig. 2B), which leads to abnormal secretion of enzymes and other substances in the cells, resulting in cell damage. It is also reported that the graphene's toxicity is related to the production method (Chng and Pumera, 2013). Different production methods will produce different physical properties, which will change the graphene's toxicity (Hu and Zhou, 2013). In addition, previous studies have shown that the change in the properties of graphene can reduce its own toxicity, and organic coupling of graphene oxide can also reduce the effects of graphene oxide on microorganisms (Jastrzebska et al., 2012).

sections.heading: 6. Comparison of different CNMs' effects on microbial communities
sections.text:
Through the above review we have discussed, we can clearly notice that different CNMs have different effects on different microorganisms. Fullerene has less influence on microbial communities than other CNMs (Hao et al., 2018). Conversely, graphene has a great influence on microbial communities (Qu et al., 2015). In addition, the effect of SWCNTs on microbial communities is significantly higher than that of MWCNTs (Qu et al., 2016). This may be due to differences in their diameter, specific surface area, and the like. Their toxicity mechanisms are similar, and the final result are making a damage to the cell membrane of the microorganisms and producing reactive oxygen species, resulting in the changes in substances' composition and activity in the microbial cells (Magrez, 2006). From the literature we have analyzed, it can be deduced that the microbial cell membrane is the last line of defense to protect microorganisms from CNMs. Once the microbial cell membrane is damaged, the microbes will inevitably receive different degrees of damage. In addition, organic matter can mitigate the effects of CNMs on microorganisms, so we can protect microbial cells against CNMS by enhancing the tolerance of microbial cell membranes to CNMs or by appropriately increasing the amount of organic matter in the microbial living environment. In water treatment systems, MWCNTs have toxic
effects on most bacteria, at 37 °C, MWCNTs can reduce the number of E. coli, P. aeruginosa and S. epidermidis by 2–3 times after 1 h, and this effect will be intensified with the extension of time (Kang et al., 2009; Srivastava et al., 2004). Similarly, SWCNTs could reduce the amount of bacteria and viruses in water, which can decrease the harm of bacteria and viruses to humans (Brady-Estevez et al., 2008), but on the other hand, this also has an negative impact on the effectiveness of sewage treatment (Luongo and Zhang, 2010). However, it is worth noting that low concentration of MWCNTs and SWCNTs can respectively promote the growth of microorganisms capable of decomposing crude oil and decomposing phenolic substances (Abbasian et al., 2016; Qu et al., 2015). In addition, related research has found that composite nanomaterials are superior in physical properties and chemical properties compared to ordinary nanomaterials, and thus can be more widely applied to environmental remediation (Mauter and Elimelech, 2008). In the soil environment, fullerenes could increase the proportion of gramnegative bacteria in the soil, thus ensuring that gram-negative bacteria work normally (Tong et al., 2007). In addition, studies have found that soil treated with graphene could promote the activity of soil microorganisms and enzymes in a short time, which could accelerate the material circulation and pollutant removal in the soil (Ren et al., 2015). Besides, studies have shown that graphene in soil could adversely affect the nutrient cycling in the soil by changing the structure of the microbial community (Ren et al., 2015), in the long run, which will cause the soil compaction. Although fullerene is less toxic to microorganisms than the above three CNMs, the changes in microbial community structure and richness caused by fullerenes could also adversely affect the degradation of pollutants in the environment, resulting in the removal rate of pollutants drop, thereby promoting the accumulation of harmful substances in the environment (Tong et al., 2007). The effects and toxicity mechanisms of CNMs on microorganisms are shown in the Fig. 1 and Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: The effects of CNMs on microbial communities are mainly manifested in the community structure, biomass and abundance of microorganisms (Fig. 1). And the effects' degree depends on the type of microorganism, the concentration of CNMs and the external environment. In general, low concentrations of CNMs have played a positive role in the survival of most microorganisms, while high concentrations of CNMs are the opposite. The toxic mechanisms of CNMs to microbes are mainly to directly destroy the electrostatic equilibrium or cell membrane and organelles of microbial cells as well as to produce oxidative stress, which induces changes in lipids and proteins in microbial cells, causing abnormal metabolism of microorganisms and further cell damage (Fig. 2). Studying the influence of CNMs on microorganisms is conducive to maximizing the economic and environmental benefits of CNMs in practical applications. For example, in view of the different toxic effects of CNMs on different microorganisms, we can selectively use CNMs for sewage treatment, inhibit the growth of unfavorable microorganisms, promote the growth of beneficial microorganisms, and improve the treatment efficiency of wastewater. In addition, we can also use the characteristic of CNMs that they can destroy the viral cells to treat and control the diseases of animals and plants. In addition, related studies showed that functionalized CNMs were difficult to degrade in the environment. Therefore, the suggestion given in this article is to control the emissions of CNMs to the environment before fully understanding the specific environmental and biological effects of them.

metadata.abstractText: Carbon nanomaterials (CNMs) are widely used because of their unique advantages in recent years. At the same time, the influence of CNMs on the environment is becoming increasingly prominent. This review mainly introduces the research progress in the effects of fullerenes, multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), singlewalled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and graphene on microorganisms and their toxicity mechanisms. On this basis, we have analyzed beneficial and adverse effects of fullerenes, graphene, MWCNTs and SWCNTs to microorganisms, and discussed the similarities of the toxicity mechanisms of different CNMs on microorganisms. This review helps provide ideas on how to protect microorganisms from the impacts of carbon nanomaterials, and it will be conductive to providing a strong theoretical basis for better application of carbon nanomaterials.
